{
    Console.WriteLine($"{kvp.Key}: {kvp.Value}");
}
ConcurrentQueue and ConcurrentStack:
// Producer-Consumer pattern with ConcurrentQueue
var queue = new ConcurrentQueue();

// Producer
Task.Run(() =>
{
    for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
    {
        queue.Enqueue(new WorkItem(i));
    }
});

// Consumer
Task.Run(() =>
{
    while (true)
    {
        if (queue.TryDequeue(out var item))
        {
            ProcessWorkItem(item);
        }
        else
        {
            Thread.Sleep(10); // Wait for more items
        }
    }
});
BlockingCollection:
// Bounded producer-consumer with blocking
var blockingCollection = new BlockingCollection(boundedCapacity: 10);

// Producer (will block when capacity is reached)
Task.Run(() =>
{
    for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
    {
        blockingCollection.Add($"Item {i}");
    }
    blockingCollection.CompleteAdding();
});

// Consumer (will block when no items available)
Task.Run(() =>
{
    foreach (var item in blockingCollection.GetConsumingEnumerable())
    {
        ProcessItem(item);
    }
});

  • Use List<T> for most dynamic array needs
  • Use Dictionary<K,V> for fast key-based lookups

  • Use Queue<T> for FIFO scenarios

  • Use concurrent collections for multi-threaded scenarios
  • Pre-allocate capacity when final size is known

üîß Custom Collections - Building Your Own Data Structures

Creating custom collections allows you to build specialized data structures tailored to your specific needs. Understanding how to implement IEnumerable and custom data structures is essential for advanced C# development.

üîÑ Implementing IEnumerable - Making Collections Enumerable

Basic IEnumerable Implementation:
public class NumberSequence : IEnumerable
{
    private readonly int _start;
    private readonly int _count;
    
    public NumberSequence(int start, int count)
    {
        _start = start;
        _count = count;
    }
    
    // Generic IEnumerator
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        for (int i = 0; i < _count; i++)
        {
            yield return _start + i;
        }
    }
    
    // Non-generic IEnumerator (required by IEnumerable)
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator()
    {
        return GetEnumerator();
    }
}

// Usage
var sequence = new NumberSequence(10, 5); // 10, 11, 12, 13, 14
foreach (int number in sequence)
{
    Console.WriteLine(number);
}

// Works with LINQ
var evenNumbers = sequence.Where(n => n % 2 == 0).ToList();
Manual IEnumerator Implementation:
public class CustomRange : IEnumerable
{
    private readonly int _start;
    private readonly int _end;
    
    public CustomRange(int start, int end)
    {
        _start = start;
        _end = end;
    }
    
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        return new CustomRangeEnumerator(_start, _end);
    }
    
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator() => GetEnumerator();
    
    private class CustomRangeEnumerator : IEnumerator
    {
        private readonly int _start;
        private readonly int _end;
        private int _current;
        private bool _started;
        
        public CustomRangeEnumerator(int start, int end)
        {
            _start = start;
            _end = end;
            _current = start - 1;
            _started = false;
        }
        
        public int Current { get; private set; }
        
        object IEnumerator.Current => Current;
        
        public bool MoveNext()
        {
            if (!_started)
            {
                _current = _start;
                _started = true;
            }
            else
            {
                _current++;
            }
            
            if (_current <= _end)
            {
                Current = _current;
                return true;
            }
            
            return false;
        }
        
        public void Reset()
        {
            _current = _start - 1;
            _started = false;
        }
        
        public void Dispose()
        {
            // Clean up resources if needed
        }
    }
}

üîó Linked Lists - Dynamic Node-Based Storage

Singly Linked List Implementation:
public class Node
{
    public T Data { get; set; }
    public Node Next { get; set; }
    
    public Node(T data)
    {
        Data = data;
        Next = null;
    }
}

public class SinglyLinkedList : IEnumerable
{
    private Node _head;
    private int _count;
    
    public int Count => _count;
    public bool IsEmpty => _head == null;
    
    // Add to the beginning
    public void AddFirst(T data)
    {
        var newNode = new Node(data)
        {
            Next = _head
        };
        _head = newNode;
        _count++;
    }
    
    // Add to the end
    public void AddLast(T data)
    {
        var newNode = new Node(data);
        
        if (_head == null)
        {
            _head = newNode;
        }
        else
        {
            var current = _head;
            while (current.Next != null)
            {
                current = current.Next;
            }
            current.Next = newNode;
        }
        _count++;
    }
    
    // Remove first occurrence
    public bool Remove(T data)
    {
        if (_head == null) return false;
        
        // If head contains the data
        if (EqualityComparer.Default.Equals(_head.Data, data))
        {
            _head = _head.Next;
            _count--;
            return true;
        }
        
        // Search in the rest of the list
        var current = _head;
        while (current.Next != null)
        {
            if (EqualityComparer.Default.Equals(current.Next.Data, data))
            {
                current.Next = current.Next.Next;
                _count--;
                return true;
            }
            current = current.Next;
        }
        
        return false;
    }
    
    // Find element
    public bool Contains(T data)
    {
        var current = _head;
        while (current != null)
        {
            if (EqualityComparer.Default.Equals(current.Data, data))
                return true;
            current = current.Next;
        }
        return false;
    }
    
    // Enumeration support
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        var current = _head;
        while (current != null)
        {
            yield return current.Data;
            current = current.Next;
        }
    }
    
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator() => GetEnumerator();
    
    // Display the list
    public override string ToString()
    {
        return string.Join(" -> ", this) + " -> null";
    }
}
Doubly Linked List:
public class DoublyLinkedNode
{
    public T Data { get; set; }
    public DoublyLinkedNode Next { get; set; }
    public DoublyLinkedNode Previous { get; set; }
    
    public DoublyLinkedNode(T data)
    {
        Data = data;
    }
}

public class DoublyLinkedList : IEnumerable
{
    private DoublyLinkedNode _head;
    private DoublyLinkedNode _tail;
    private int _count;
    
    public int Count => _count;
    
    public void AddFirst(T data)
    {
        var newNode = new DoublyLinkedNode(data);
        
        if (_head == null)
        {
            _head = _tail = newNode;
        }
        else
        {
            newNode.Next = _head;
            _head.Previous = newNode;
            _head = newNode;
        }
        _count++;
    }
    
    public void AddLast(T data)
    {
        var newNode = new DoublyLinkedNode(data);
        
        if (_tail == null)
        {
            _head = _tail = newNode;
        }
        else
        {
            _tail.Next = newNode;
            newNode.Previous = _tail;
            _tail = newNode;
        }
        _count++;
    }
    
    // Enumerate forward
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        var current = _head;
        while (current != null)
        {
            yield return current.Data;
            current = current.Next;
        }
    }
    
    // Enumerate backward
    public IEnumerable Reverse()
    {
        var current = _tail;
        while (current != null)
        {
            yield return current.Data;
            current = current.Previous;
        }
    }
    
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator() => GetEnumerator();
}

Binary Tree Implementation:
public class BinaryTreeNode
{
    public T Data { get; set; }
    public BinaryTreeNode Left { get; set; }
    public BinaryTreeNode Right { get; set; }
    
    public BinaryTreeNode(T data)
    {
        Data = data;
    }
    
    public bool IsLeaf => Left == null && Right == null;
}

public class BinaryTree : IEnumerable
{
    public BinaryTreeNode Root { get; private set; }
    
    public BinaryTree(T rootData)
    {
        Root = new BinaryTreeNode(rootData);
    }
    
    // In-order traversal (Left, Root, Right)
    public IEnumerable InOrderTraversal(BinaryTreeNode node = null)
    {
        node ??= Root;
        if (node == null) yield break;
        
        foreach (var data in InOrderTraversal(node.Left))
            yield return data;
        
        yield return node.Data;
        
        foreach (var data in InOrderTraversal(node.Right))
            yield return data;
    }
    
    // Pre-order traversal (Root, Left, Right)
    public IEnumerable PreOrderTraversal(BinaryTreeNode node = null)
    {
        node ??= Root;
        if (node == null) yield break;
        
        yield return node.Data;
        
        foreach (var data in PreOrderTraversal(node.Left))
            yield return data;
        
        foreach (var data in PreOrderTraversal(node.Right))
            yield return data;
    }
    
    // Post-order traversal (Left, Right, Root)
    public IEnumerable PostOrderTraversal(BinaryTreeNode node = null)
    {
        node ??= Root;
        if (node == null) yield break;
        
        foreach (var data in PostOrderTraversal(node.Left))
            yield return data;
        
        foreach (var data in PostOrderTraversal(node.Right))
            yield return data;
        
        yield return node.Data;
    }
    
    // Level-order traversal (Breadth-first)
    public IEnumerable LevelOrderTraversal()
    {
        if (Root == null) yield break;
        
        var queue = new Queue>();
        queue.Enqueue(Root);
        
        while (queue.Count > 0)
        {
            var current = queue.Dequeue();
            yield return current.Data;
            
            if (current.Left != null)
                queue.Enqueue(current.Left);
            
            if (current.Right != null)
                queue.Enqueue(current.Right);
        }
    }
    
    // Default enumeration (in-order)
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        return InOrderTraversal().GetEnumerator();
    }
    
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator() => GetEnumerator();
}
Binary Search Tree (BST):
public class BinarySearchTree : IEnumerable where T : IComparable
{
    private BinaryTreeNode _root;
    
    public void Insert(T data)
    {
        _root = InsertRecursive(_root, data);
    }
    
    private BinaryTreeNode InsertRecursive(BinaryTreeNode node, T data)
    {
        if (node == null)
            return new BinaryTreeNode(data);
        
        int comparison = data.CompareTo(node.Data);
        
        if (comparison < 0)
            node.Left = InsertRecursive(node.Left, data);
        else if (comparison > 0)
            node.Right = InsertRecursive(node.Right, data);
        // If equal, we don't insert (no duplicates)
        
        return node;
    }
    
    public bool Search(T data)
    {
        return SearchRecursive(_root, data);
    }
    
    private bool SearchRecursive(BinaryTreeNode node, T data)
    {
        if (node == null) return false;
        
        int comparison = data.CompareTo(node.Data);
        
        if (comparison == 0) return true;
        if (comparison < 0) return SearchRecursive(node.Left, data);
        return SearchRecursive(node.Right, data);
    }
    
    public void Delete(T data)
    {
        _root = DeleteRecursive(_root, data);
    }
    
    private BinaryTreeNode DeleteRecursive(BinaryTreeNode node, T data)
    {
        if (node == null) return null;
        
        int comparison = data.CompareTo(node.Data);
        
        if (comparison < 0)
        {
            node.Left = DeleteRecursive(node.Left, data);
        }
        else if (comparison > 0)
        {
            node.Right = DeleteRecursive(node.Right, data);
        }
        else
        {
            // Node to delete found
            if (node.Left == null) return node.Right;
            if (node.Right == null) return node.Left;
            
            // Node has two children
            T minValue = FindMin(node.Right);
            node.Data = minValue;
            node.Right = DeleteRecursive(node.Right, minValue);
        }
        
        return node;
    }
    
    private T FindMin(BinaryTreeNode node)
    {
        while (node.Left != null)
            node = node.Left;
        return node.Data;
    }
    
    // In-order traversal gives sorted order
    public IEnumerator GetEnumerator()
    {
        return InOrderTraversal(_root).GetEnumerator();
    }
    
    private IEnumerable InOrderTraversal(BinaryTreeNode node)
    {
        if (node == null) yield break;
        
        foreach (var data in InOrderTraversal(node.Left))
            yield return data;
        
        yield return node.Data;
        
        foreach (var data in InOrderTraversal(node.Right))
            yield return data;
    }
    
    IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator() => GetEnumerator();
}

Proper error handling and debugging skills are essential for creating reliable applications. Understanding exceptions, debugging techniques, and logging strategies helps you build resilient software.

‚ö†Ô∏è Exception Handling - Managing Exceptional Conditions

Try-Catch-Finally Structure:
public class FileProcessor
{
    public string ProcessFile(string filePath)
    {
        StreamReader reader = null;
        try
        {
            // Code that might throw exceptions
            reader = new StreamReader(filePath);
            string content = reader.ReadToEnd();
            
            // Process the content
            return ProcessContent(content);
        }
        catch (FileNotFoundException ex)
        {
            // Handle specific exception type
            Console.WriteLine($"File not found: {ex.FileName}");
            throw; // Re-throw to preserve stack trace
        }
        catch (UnauthorizedAccessException ex)
        {
            // Handle another specific exception
            Console.WriteLine($"Access denied: {ex.Message}");
            return string.Empty; // Graceful recovery
        }
        catch (IOException ex)
        {
            // Handle broader category
            Console.WriteLine($"IO error occurred: {ex.Message}");
            throw new ProcessingException("Failed to process file", ex); // Wrap exception
        }
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            // Catch-all for unexpected exceptions
            Console.WriteLine($"Unexpected error: {ex.Message}");
            throw; // Re-throw unknown exceptions
        }
        finally
        {
            // Always executed - cleanup code
            reader?.Dispose();
            Console.WriteLine("Cleanup completed");
        }
    }
}

Retry Pattern:
public class RetryHelper
{
    public static async Task RetryAsync(
        Func> operation,
        int maxAttempts = 3,
        TimeSpan delay = default)
    {
        if (delay == default) delay = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(1);
        
        Exception lastException = null;
        
        for (int attempt = 1; attempt <= maxAttempts; attempt++)
        {
            try
            {
                return await operation();
            }
            catch (Exception ex) when (IsRetriableException(ex))
            {
                lastException = ex;
                
                if (attempt == maxAttempts)
                    break;
                
                Console.WriteLine($"Attempt {attempt} failed, retrying in {delay.TotalSeconds}s...");
                await Task.Delay(delay);
                
                // Exponential backoff
                delay = TimeSpan.FromMilliseconds(delay.TotalMilliseconds * 2);
            }
        }
        
        throw new RetryExhaustedException(
            $"Operation failed after {maxAttempts} attempts", lastException);
    }
    
    private static bool IsRetriableException(Exception ex)
    {
        return ex is HttpRequestException ||
               ex is TimeoutException ||
               ex is SocketException;
    }
}
Circuit Breaker Pattern:
public class CircuitBreaker
{
    private int _failureCount = 0;
    private DateTime _lastFailureTime = DateTime.MinValue;
    private readonly int _threshold;
    private readonly TimeSpan _timeout;
    private CircuitState _state = CircuitState.Closed;
    
    public CircuitBreaker(int threshold = 5, TimeSpan timeout = default)
    {
        _threshold = threshold;
        _timeout = timeout == default ? TimeSpan.FromMinutes(1) : timeout;
    }
    
    public async Task ExecuteAsync(Func> operation)
    {
        if (_state == CircuitState.Open)
        {
            if (DateTime.UtcNow - _lastFailureTime > _timeout)
            {
                _state = CircuitState.HalfOpen;
            }
            else
            {
                throw new CircuitBreakerOpenException("Circuit breaker is open");
            }
        }
        
        try
        {
            var result = await operation();
            OnSuccess();
            return result;
        }
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            OnFailure();
            throw;
        }
    }
    
    private void OnSuccess()
    {
        _failureCount = 0;
        _state = CircuitState.Closed;
    }
    
    private void OnFailure()
    {
        _failureCount++;
        _lastFailureTime = DateTime.UtcNow;
        
        if (_failureCount >= _threshold)
        {
            _state = CircuitState.Open;
        }
    }
}

public enum CircuitState { Closed, Open, HalfOpen }

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls

  • Swallowing exceptions: Catching and ignoring exceptions without logging
  • Throwing generic exceptions: Using Exception instead of specific types
  • Breaking stack traces: Using 'throw ex' instead of 'throw'
  • Overusing exceptions: Using exceptions for control flow
  • Missing finally blocks: Not cleaning up resources
  • Debugging in production: Leaving debug code in release builds

üèÜ Best Practices

  • Catch specific exceptions rather than Exception
  • Use 'throw' to preserve stack traces when re-throwing
  • Log exceptions with context and correlation IDs
  • Use structured logging for better searchability
  • Implement proper cleanup in finally blocks
  • Create meaningful custom exception types
  • Use exception filters for conditional handling
  • Don't catch exceptions you can't handle meaningfully
  • Use debugging attributes to improve debugging experience
  • Implement retry and circuit breaker patterns for resilience

üéØ Delegates & Events - Functional Programming and Observer Pattern

Delegates and events are fundamental C# concepts that enable functional programming patterns, callbacks, and the observer pattern. They provide type-safe function pointers and event-driven programming capabilities.

üîó Delegates - Type-Safe Function Pointers

Basic Delegate Declaration and Usage:
// Delegate declaration
public delegate int MathOperation(int a, int b);
public delegate void NotificationHandler(string message);
public delegate bool Predicate(T item);

public class DelegateBasics
{
    // Methods that match delegate signatures
    public static int Add(int a, int b) => a + b;
    public static int Multiply(int a, int b) => a * b;
    public static int Subtract(int a, int b) => a - b;
    
    public static void LogMessage(string message)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"[LOG] {DateTime.Now}: {message}");
    }
    
    public static void EmailNotification(string message)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"[EMAIL] Sending: {message}");
    }
    
    public static void DemonstrateBasicDelegates()
    {
        // Single delegate assignment
        MathOperation operation = Add;
        int result = operation(5, 3); // 8
        
        // Changing delegate target
        operation = Multiply;
        result = operation(5, 3); // 15
        
        // Multicast delegates
        NotificationHandler notify = LogMessage;
        notify += EmailNotification; // Add another method
        
        notify("System started"); // Calls both methods
        
        notify -= LogMessage; // Remove a method
        notify("User logged in"); // Calls only EmailNotification
    }
}
Built-in Delegate Types:
// Action delegates (no return value)
Action simpleAction = () => Console.WriteLine("Hello");
Action messageAction = msg => Console.WriteLine(msg);
Action paramAction = (id, name) => Console.WriteLine($"ID: {id}, Name: {name}");

// Func delegates (with return value)
Func getNumber = () => 42;
Func addNumbers = (a, b) => a + b;
Func isValidEmail = email => email.Contains("@");
Func, int> getSum = numbers => numbers.Sum();

// Predicate delegate (returns bool)
Predicate isEven = x => x % 2 == 0;
Predicate isNotEmpty = s => !string.IsNullOrEmpty(s);

// Usage examples
public void DemonstrateBuiltInDelegates()
{
    // Using Action

    public static class WeakEventManager where TEventArgs : EventArgs
    {
        private static readonly List _handlers = new();
        
        public static void AddHandler(EventHandler handler)
        {
            _handlers.Add(new WeakReference(handler));
        }
        
        public static void RemoveHandler(EventHandler handler)
        {
            for (int i = _handlers.Count - 1; i >= 0; i--)
            {
                if (!_handlers[i].IsAlive || _handlers[i].Target?.Equals(handler) == true)
                {
                    _handlers.RemoveAt(i);
                }
            }
        }
        
        public static void RaiseEvent(object? sender, TEventArgs e)
        {
            for (int i = _handlers.Count - 1; i >= 0; i--)
            {
                if (_handlers[i].IsAlive && _handlers[i].Target is EventHandler handler)
                {
                    handler(sender, e);
                }
                else
                {
                    _handlers.RemoveAt(i); // Clean up dead references
                }
            }
        }
    }

public class CommandPattern

        private double _value = 0;
        
        public double Value => _value;

        {
            command.Execute();
            _history.Push(command);
            Console.WriteLine($"Executed: {command.Description}, Value: {_value}");
        }
        
        public void Undo()
        {
            if (_history.Count > 0)
            {
                var command = _history.Pop();
                command.Undo();
                Console.WriteLine($"Undid: {command.Description}, Value: {_value}");
            }
        }

                undo: () => _value -= amount,

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls

  • Memory leaks: Not unsubscribing from events
  • Null reference exceptions: Not checking for null before invoking delegates
  • Exception handling: One handler's exception can prevent other handlers from executing
  • Closure capture: Capturing loop variables incorrectly
  • Thread safety: Race conditions when adding/removing event handlers

üèÜ Best Practices

  • Use null-conditional operator (?.) when invoking delegates
  • Always unsubscribe from events to prevent memory leaks
  • Use EventHandler for custom events
  • Make event raising methods protected virtual for inheritance
  • Handle exceptions in multicast delegates appropriately
  • Consider using weak references for long-lived event sources
  • Use local functions instead of lambdas when recursion is needed
  • Prefer Action/Func over custom delegate types when possible

LINQ (Language Integrated Query) revolutionizes data querying in C# by providing a unified syntax for querying various data sources. It enables functional programming patterns and makes complex data operations readable and composable.

public void DemonstrateQuerySyntax()
{

                     where n % 2 == 0

                      where n % 2 == 0

    // Complex query with multiple clauses
    var complexQuery = from n in numbers
                      where n > 3
                      orderby n descending
                      select new { Number = n, Square = n * n };
    
    // Grouping in query syntax
    var grouped = from n in numbers
                 group n by n % 3 into g
                 select new { Remainder = g.Key, Numbers = g.ToList() };

public class EnumerableExample

        IEnumerable query = numbers
            .Where(n => n % 2 == 0)     // Executes in C#
            .Select(n => n * n);        // Executes in C#
        
        // Deferred execution - query not executed until enumerated
        Console.WriteLine("Query created, not executed yet");
        
        // Execution happens here
        foreach (var result in query)
        {

        // Multiple enumeration causes re-execution
        var list1 = query.ToList(); // Executes query
        var list2 = query.ToList(); // Executes query again!
        
        // Force immediate execution
        var materializedQuery = numbers
            .Where(n => n % 2 == 0)
            .Select(n => n * n)
            .ToList(); // Immediate execution
    }

            .Where(c => c.Age > 18)      // SQL WHERE clause
            .OrderBy(c => c.LastName)    // SQL ORDER BY clause
            .ToList();                   // Database hit with filtered results

            .Where(c => c.Age > 18)

public static class CustomLinqExtensions
{
    // Extension method for chunking
    public static IEnumerable> Chunk(this IEnumerable source, int size)
    {
        var chunk = new List(size);
        
        foreach (var item in source)
        {
            chunk.Add(item);
            
            if (chunk.Count == size)
            {
                yield return chunk;
                chunk = new List(size);
            }
        }
        
        if (chunk.Count > 0)
            yield return chunk;
    }
    
    // Extension method for conditional filtering
    public static IEnumerable WhereIf(this IEnumerable source, 
        bool condition, Func predicate)
    {
        return condition ? source.Where(predicate) : source;
    }
    
    // Extension method for safe Max/Min
    public static T? SafeMax(this IEnumerable source) where T : IComparable
    {
        using var enumerator = source.GetEnumerator();
        if (!enumerator.MoveNext())
            return default(T);
        
        var max = enumerator.Current;
        while (enumerator.MoveNext())
        {
            if (enumerator.Current.CompareTo(max) > 0)
                max = enumerator.Current;
        }
        
        return max;
    }
    
    // Extension method for pagination
    public static IEnumerable Page(this IEnumerable source, int pageNumber, int pageSize)
    {
        return source.Skip((pageNumber - 1) * pageSize).Take(pageSize);
    }
}

            .Take(100)
            .ToList();

    private bool IsPrime(int number)
    {
        if (number < 2) return false;
        for (int i = 2; i <= Math.Sqrt(number); i++)
        {
            if (number % i == 0) return false;
        }
        return true;
    }

Asynchronous programming allows your application to remain responsive while performing long-running operations. Understanding async/await, Tasks, and cancellation is crucial for modern C# development.

    {

    {
        // Task.Run for CPU-bound work
        Task task1 = Task.Run(() =>
        {
            Thread.Sleep(1000); // Simulate CPU work
            return 42;
        });
        
        // Task.FromResult for already computed values
        Task task2 = Task.FromResult("Immediate result");
        
        // Task.CompletedTask for void operations
        Task task3 = Task.CompletedTask;
        
        // TaskCompletionSource for custom async operations
        var tcs = new TaskCompletionSource();
        Task task4 = tcs.Task;
        
        // Complete the task later
        Task.Run(async () =>
        {
            await Task.Delay(2000);
            tcs.SetResult(true);
        });
    }

public class ConnectedDataAccess
{
    private readonly string _connectionString;
    
    public ConnectedDataAccess(string connectionString)
    {
        _connectionString = connectionString;
    }
    
    // Execute scalar query (single value)
    public async Task ExecuteScalarAsync(string sql, params SqlParameter[] parameters)
    {
        using var connection = new SqlConnection(_connectionString);
        using var command = new SqlCommand(sql, connection);
        
        if (parameters.Length > 0)
            command.Parameters.AddRange(parameters);
        
        await connection.OpenAsync();
        var result = await command.ExecuteScalarAsync();
        
        return result is DBNull || result == null ? default(T) : (T)result;
    }
    
    // Execute non-query (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE)
    public async Task ExecuteNonQueryAsync(string sql, params SqlParameter[] parameters)
    {
        using var connection = new SqlConnection(_connectionString);
        using var command = new SqlCommand(sql, connection);
        
        if (parameters.Length > 0)
            command.Parameters.AddRange(parameters);
        
        await connection.OpenAsync();
        return await command.ExecuteNonQueryAsync();
    }
    
    // Execute reader for multiple rows
    public async Task> ExecuteReaderAsync(string sql, Func mapper, params SqlParameter[] parameters)
    {
        var results = new List();
        
        using var connection = new SqlConnection(_connectionString);
        using var command = new SqlCommand(sql, connection);
        
        if (parameters.Length > 0)
            command.Parameters.AddRange(parameters);
        
        await connection.OpenAsync();
        using var reader = await command.ExecuteReaderAsync();
        
        while (await reader.ReadAsync())
        {
            results.Add(mapper(reader));
        }
        
        return results;
    }
    
    // Streaming data with IAsyncEnumerable
    public async IAsyncEnumerable ExecuteReaderStreamAsync(
        string sql, 
        Func mapper, 
        [EnumeratorCancellation] CancellationToken cancellationToken = default, 
        params SqlParameter[] parameters)
    {
        using var connection = new SqlConnection(_connectionString);
        using var command = new SqlCommand(sql, connection);
        
        if (parameters.Length > 0)
            command.Parameters.AddRange(parameters);
        
        await connection.OpenAsync(cancellationToken);
        using var reader = await command.ExecuteReaderAsync(cancellationToken);
        
        while (await reader.ReadAsync(cancellationToken))
        {
            cancellationToken.ThrowIfCancellationRequested();
            yield return mapper(reader);
        }
    }
}

public class TransactionExamples

    // Basic transaction
    public async Task TransferFundsAsync(int fromAccountId, int toAccountId, decimal amount)
    {
        using var connection = new SqlConnection(_connectionString);
        await connection.OpenAsync();
        
        using var transaction = connection.BeginTransaction();
        
        try
        {
            // Debit from source account
            using var debitCommand = new SqlCommand(
                "UPDATE Accounts SET Balance = Balance - @Amount WHERE Id = @AccountId",
                connection, transaction);
            
            debitCommand.Parameters.AddWithValue("@Amount", amount);
            debitCommand.Parameters.AddWithValue("@AccountId", fromAccountId);
            
            var debitResult = await debitCommand.ExecuteNonQueryAsync();
            if (debitResult != 1)
                throw new InvalidOperationException("Failed to debit source account");
            
            // Credit to destination account
            using var creditCommand = new SqlCommand(
                "UPDATE Accounts SET Balance = Balance + @Amount WHERE Id = @AccountId",
                connection, transaction);
            
            creditCommand.Parameters.AddWithValue("@Amount", amount);
            creditCommand.Parameters.AddWithValue("@AccountId", toAccountId);
            
            var creditResult = await creditCommand.ExecuteNonQueryAsync();
            if (creditResult != 1)
                throw new InvalidOperationException("Failed to credit destination account");
            
            // Commit transaction
            transaction.Commit();
            return true;
        }
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            // Rollback on any error
            transaction.Rollback();
            Console.WriteLine($"Transaction failed: {ex.Message}");
            return false;
        }
    }

    {

                foreach (var user in batch)
                {
                    sqlBuilder.AppendLine($"UPDATE Users SET Name = @Name{parameterIndex}, Email = @Email{parameterIndex} WHERE Id = @Id{parameterIndex};");
                    
                    command.Parameters.AddWithValue($"@Name{parameterIndex}", user.Name);
                    command.Parameters.AddWithValue($"@Email{parameterIndex}", user.Email ?? (object)DBNull.Value);
                    command.Parameters.AddWithValue($"@Id{parameterIndex}", user.Id);
                    
                    parameterIndex++;
                }
                
                command.CommandText = sqlBuilder.ToString();
                totalAffected += await command.ExecuteNonQueryAsync();
            }
            
            transaction.Commit();
            return totalAffected;
        }
        catch
        {
            transaction.Rollback();
            throw;
        }
    }
    
    // Connection pooling optimization
    public static string GetOptimizedConnectionString(string server, string database)
    {
        return new SqlConnectionStringBuilder
        {
            DataSource = server,
            InitialCatalog = database,
            IntegratedSecurity = true,
            Pooling = true,
            MinPoolSize = 5,      // Minimum connections in pool
            MaxPoolSize = 100,    // Maximum connections in pool
            ConnectionTimeout = 15, // Connection timeout in seconds
            CommandTimeout = 30,   // Command timeout in seconds
            LoadBalanceTimeout = 0, // Connection lifetime in seconds (0 = infinite)
            Enlist = true,         // Enable automatic transaction enlistment
        }.ConnectionString;
    }
    
    private DataTable ConvertToDataTable(IEnumerable users)
    {
        var dataTable = new DataTable();
        dataTable.Columns.Add("Name", typeof(string));
        dataTable.Columns.Add("Email", typeof(string));
        dataTable.Columns.Add("CreatedDate", typeof(DateTime));
        
        foreach (var user in users)
        {
            dataTable.Rows.Add(user.Name, user.Email, user.CreatedDate);
        }
        
        return dataTable;
    }
}

public class BloggingContext : DbContext

            entity.Property(b => b.Description).HasMaxLength(1000);
            entity.HasIndex(b => b.Title).IsUnique();

        {
            entity.HasKey(p => p.Id);
            entity.Property(p => p.Title).IsRequired().HasMaxLength(300);
            entity.Property(p => p.Content).IsRequired();
            
            // Configure foreign key relationship
            entity.HasOne(p => p.Blog)
                  .WithMany(b => b.Posts)
                  .HasForeignKey(p => p.BlogId)
                  .OnDelete(DeleteBehavior.Cascade);
        });
        
        modelBuilder.Entity(entity =>
        {
            entity.HasKey(c => c.Id);
            entity.Property(c => c.Author).IsRequired().HasMaxLength(100);
            entity.Property(c => c.Content).IsRequired().HasMaxLength(500);
            
            entity.HasOne(c => c.Post)
                  .WithMany(p => p.Comments)

public class BlogService

    public async Task CreateBlogAsync(string title, string description)
    {
        var blog = new Blog
        {
            Title = title,
            Description = description,
            CreatedDate = DateTime.UtcNow
        };
        
        _context.Blogs.Add(blog);
        await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
        
        return blog;
    }

    public async Task GetBlogByIdAsync(int id)
    {
        return await _context.Blogs.FindAsync(id);
    }

    {
        return await _context.Blogs
            .OrderBy(b => b.Title)
            .ToListAsync();
    }
    
    // Read - Complex queries with navigation properties
    public async Task GetBlogWithPostsAsync(int id)
    {
        return await _context.Blogs
            .Include(b => b.Posts)
                .ThenInclude(p => p.Comments)
            .FirstOrDefaultAsync(b => b.Id == id);
    }
    
    // Read - Filtered and paged queries
    public async Task> GetBlogsPagedAsync(int page, int pageSize, string? searchTerm = null)
    {
        var query = _context.Blogs.AsQueryable();
        
        if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(searchTerm))
        {
            query = query.Where(b => b.Title.Contains(searchTerm) || b.Description.Contains(searchTerm));
        }
        
        return await query
            .OrderBy(b => b.Title)
            .Skip((page - 1) * pageSize)
            .Take(pageSize)
            .ToListAsync();
    }
    
    // Update
    public async Task UpdateBlogAsync(int id, string title, string description)
    {
        var blog = await _context.Blogs.FindAsync(id);
        if (blog == null)
            throw new ArgumentException($"Blog with id {id} not found");
        
        blog.Title = title;
        blog.Description = description;
        
        await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
        return blog;
    }
    
    // Update - Bulk update
    public async Task UpdateBlogCategoryAsync(string oldCategory, string newCategory)
    {
        return await _context.Blogs
            .Where(b => b.Description.Contains(oldCategory))
            .ExecuteUpdateAsync(b => b.SetProperty(blog => blog.Description, 
                blog => blog.Description.Replace(oldCategory, newCategory)));
    }
    
    // Delete
    public async Task DeleteBlogAsync(int id)
    {
        var blog = await _context.Blogs.FindAsync(id);
        if (blog == null)
            return false;
        
        _context.Blogs.Remove(blog);
        await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
        return true;
    }

    {

            .Where(b => b.CreatedDate < cutoffDate)
            .ExecuteDeleteAsync();

public class PerformanceOptimization
{
    private readonly BloggingContext _context;
    
    public PerformanceOptimization(BloggingContext context)
    {
        _context = context;
    }
    
    // Bulk operations
    public async Task BulkInsertPostsAsync(List posts)
    {
        // Disable change tracking for bulk operations
        _context.ChangeTracker.AutoDetectChangesEnabled = false;
        
        try
        {
            await _context.Posts.AddRangeAsync(posts);
            await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
        }
        finally
        {
            _context.ChangeTracker.AutoDetectChangesEnabled = true;
        }
    }
    
    // Optimized updates
    public async Task OptimizedUpdateAsync(int blogId, string newTitle)
    {
        // Direct update without loading entity
        await _context.Blogs
            .Where(b => b.Id == blogId)
            .ExecuteUpdateAsync(b => b.SetProperty(blog => blog.Title, newTitle));
    }
    
    // Batch loading
    public async Task>> LoadPostsForBlogsAsync(List blogIds)
    {
        var posts = await _context.Posts
            .Where(p => blogIds.Contains(p.BlogId))
            .ToListAsync();
            
        return posts.GroupBy(p => p.BlogId)
                   .ToDictionary(g => g.Key, g => g.ToList());
    }
    
    // Connection resiliency
    public async Task> GetBlogsWithRetryAsync()
    {
        var strategy = _context.Database.CreateExecutionStrategy();
        
        return await strategy.ExecuteAsync(async () =>
        {
            using var context = new BloggingContext(_context.Options);
            return await context.Blogs.ToListAsync();
        });
    }
    
    // Memory optimization for large datasets
    public async IAsyncEnumerable GetPostsStreamAsync()
    {
        await foreach (var post in _context.Posts.AsAsyncEnumerable())
        {
            yield return post;
        }
    }
